outlooksByWeek.1: Murray finished 2019 with the eighth-most points among quarterbacks, but ended the season with 13-or-fewer points in four of his final five outings. He did well against the 49ers last season and he'll get a chance to face them again in Week 1, but they did allow the ninth-fewest points to passers a year ago. Therefore, Murray is only a borderline starting candidate to open the season.
outlooksByWeek.2: The fact that Murray could come away from a matchup with a very tough San Francisco defense with a more-than-startworthy 26 fantasy points says a lot about the second-year pro. He gets a break this week against Washington, a defense that allowed the seventh-most QB fantasy points in 2019. Lock in Murray as a starter in all formats for this fantastic matchup.
outlooksByWeek.3: One of the best quarterbacks of the 2020 season gets a matchup with last season's sixth-best defense for opposing passers. This seems like an easy choice. Murray offers so much upside thanks to his running ability (158 yards and three scores through two games) and is easily one of the top overall choices at the QB position in Week 3. Start him with confidence.

player.seasonOutlook: Murray's rookie season had its ups and downs, which is exactly what you'd expect from a first-year starting quarterback. The 2019 first overall pick struggled to 6.9 YPA and took a league-high 48 sacks, but he also finished strong by leading the Arizona offense to three-plus touchdowns in eight of the team's final 11 games. Murray's rushing ability helped him to a 93-544-4 rushing line (top-four in all three categories) and an eighth-place finish in fantasy points. Murray was already a strong bet for a second-year leap, but the addition of DeAndre Hopkins further adds to his appeal. The hype might lead to an irresponsible ADP, but there's little doubt Murray has elite upside. He's a solid fantasy starter.

outlooksByWeek.1: Hopkins has thrived with varying levels of quality at quarterback in his career. Now he gets the chance to line up alongside a rising star in Kyler Murray. That should be a great opportunity for the veteran out of Clemson.  He gets a perfectly fine matchup against a decent 49ers pass defense (12th-fewest WR points allowed last year) in Week 1. He's a must-start every week, and this is no exception.
outlooksByWeek.2: Hopkins found immediate chemistry with his new QB, Kyler Murray, hauling in an incredible 14 passes against a tough 49ers defense. Expect more of the same in Week 2 against a less-impressive Washington pass defense. Consider Hopkins to be a top-tier option heading into Week 2.
outlooksByWeek.3: Hopkins took a step back in Week 2, "only" scoring one touchdown on nine targets, eight of which were caught. Through two weeks, the former Texans star has at least double the receptions, targets and yards of any other Arizona pass-catcher. He remains the top option in an offense on the rise under second-year passer Kyler Murray. Against a porous Detroit defense, Hopkins is an elite WR1 for Week 3.

player.seasonOutlook: Hopkins was traded to the Cardinals during the offseason and will now operate as Kyler Murray's go-to target. A top-five fantasy WR in four of the past five seasons, Hopkins has averaged 10.5 targets per game during that span, which is a mark he should still be able to approach with Arizona. Murray is far from a finished product, but the Cardinals' offense finished 2019 strong with three-plus touchdowns in eight of their final 11 games -- and that was without one of the game's best receivers. At age 28, Hopkins remains an elite fantasy option and should be selected near the first/second-round turn.

outlooksByWeek.1: Drake emerged as the lead back for the Cardinals late last season and never looked back. He enters 2020 as one of the better options at the RB position given his high volume and pass-catching ability. The 49ers have a formidable run defense, allowing the second-fewest RB points a year ago, but don't let that slow you down. Drake is a must-start until his role drastically changes.
outlooksByWeek.2: Drake did not see a lot of work in the passing game with DeAndre Hopkins dominating the targets among pass-catchers, but he did get a healthy 16 carries and scored a touchdown against a sturdy San Francisco defense. This week, he'll take on a Washington team that allowed the third-most RB points last season, so there is no reason to take Drake out of your lineup heading into Week 2.
outlooksByWeek.3: Drake received a healthy 20 carries against Washington in Week 8 and provided a respectable 86 yards on the ground, but his lack of contributions in the passing game so far this season are certainly suboptimal for those banking on him as an every-week back. With only four targets and 14 receiving yards in two games, we want to see more from Drake in the passing game lest we start to slide him down from RB1/RB2 status to more of a flex pick. For now, keep him locked in, especially against a lackluster Lions defense.

player.seasonOutlook: Drake received the transition tag from the Cardinals during the offseason and will return as the team's clear feature back. Traded from Miami to Arizona at the 2019 trade deadline, Drake went on to play 381 (79%) of 483 possible snaps during his eight games with the team. He handled 66% of the team's carries (15.4 per game) and 14% of the targets (4.4) during that span. That heavy usage allowed him the fourth-most fantasy points among RBs during that span. Arizona's offense should only improve in Kliff Kingsbury and Kyler Murray's second season, so Drake, who sports an impressive 4.8 career YPC, is very much in the RB1 discussion.

outlooksByWeek.1: Fitzgerald has not missed a game since 2014 and, while he is definitely at the tail-end of his career, he's more than good enough to deserve a look in your fantasy lineup every now and then. That said, the 49ers are a middling matchup for opposing wideouts and Fitzgerald has plenty of competition for catches in Week 1 if everyone is healthy. As such, he's best left on the bench for this one.
outlooksByWeek.2: Through one week, it's apparent that the veteran receiver isn't going anywhere. He finished with the second-most receptions among Cardinals in Week 1, and now takes on a much weaker defense in Week 2. Washington might have surprised folks in Week 1, but this is a team that allowed an above-average amount of points to wideouts last season. Fitzgerald is a low-ceiling flex pick in deeper leagues for as long as he's a regular part of this Arizona offense.
outlooksByWeek.3: The veteran receiver made a bit of a splash in Week 2, hauling in seven passes and playing on a healthy 61 snaps on offense. Yet, with DeAndre Hopkins leading Arizona's pass-catching corps and Kyler Murray providing production with his running, Fitzgerald and teammate Christian Kirk are left to split a small share of the Cardinals offense. Neither is a great option this week, but in a great matchup with the Lions, they can both be  considered as low-end flex picks.

player.seasonOutlook: Fitzgerald is back for his 17th NFL season. Arizona's primary slot receiver put together another solid season in 2019, ranking 17th in the league in receptions (75), while not dropping a single one of his 108 targets. No longer a downfield threat, Fitzgerald has ranked in the 17th percentile or lower in YPR in each of the past five seasons and hasn't cleared six touchdowns since 2015. Fitzgerald's role limited him to just one weekly finish better than 19th last season (ninth in Week 1). Fitzgerald is entering his age-37 season and his targets will take another hit with DeAndre Hopkins now in the fold. Fitzgerald has a very low ceiling and is only an option in very deep PPR leagues.

After failing to make an impact during his first two NFL seasons, Gonzalez surged to the sixth-most fantasy points at the position in 2019. In what was his first full season with Arizona, Gonzalez produced 11 top-10 fantasy weeks, which tied for most. His 35 field goal attempts were third most in the league and, though his 88.6% field goal percentage was eighth best, it was certainly inflated by an average distance of 33.5 yards, which was the shortest in the league. Arizona's offense is a candidate for a leap in quarterback Kyler Murray's second season, which makes Gonzalez a fine last-round flier.

outlooksByWeek.1: Edmonds had long been seen as a backup plan to David Johnson. Now that the Northern Iowa product is no longer a member of the Cardinals, Edmonds nevertheless retains his role as No. 2 on Arizona's RB depth chart behind a fantasy star starter. Kenyan Drake is the Arizona back you want, but Edmonds could have big value if Drake were to be sidelined.
outlooksByWeek.2: Kenyan Drake and Kyler Murray combined for 29 carries in Week 1, but there was still room for six rushing attempts and five passing-game targets (including one that ended in a touchdown) for the team's No. 2 running back. Edmonds is a name to keep an eye on, especially if you have Drake on your roster. Still, his role isn't big enough yet to merit a start in fantasy.
outlooksByWeek.3: Edmonds provides valuable snaps off the bench for Arizona, and his involvement in the passing game is encouraging. Still, he's not yet involved enough to be considered for a spot in your starting lineup. Keep him on the bench in case anything happens to Kenyan Drake.

player.seasonOutlook: Edmonds is expected to enter the 2020 season as Kenyan Drake's primary backup. The third-year back has operated as a reserve in 28 of 29 career games, but the one exception was an explosive Week 7 effort against the Giants last season in which he put up 150 yards and three scores on 29 touches. Edmonds went on to touch the ball nine times the rest of the season while dealing with injuries and the emergence of Drake. Edmonds' backup status is all but secured with David Johnson no longer in the mix (seventh-round pick Eno Benjamin is his chief competition), so though the 24-year-old has no stand-alone value, he's valuable insurance and thus worth a stash in deeper leagues.

outlooksByWeek.1: The speedster slowly made gains as a wideout in his rookie season, but he's buried on Arizona's WR depth chart behind a pair of veterans both likely earmarked for Canton (Larry Fitzgerald and DeAndre Hopkins) and young Christian Kirk. He's a name to keep an eye on, as his speed can lead to some huge plays. For now, though, he's best left on the fantasy sidelines.
outlooksByWeek.2: Isabella is the No. 4 receiver for the Cardinals, and the gap between him and the No. 3 receiver on the Arizona depth chart is quite large. He is not on the field often enough to merit a spot in your fantasy lineups in Week 2.
outlooksByWeek.3: The speedy sophomore made an impact in Week 2, picking up 67 yards on two receptions, but he will need a major shakeup on Arizona's WR depth chart to merit a spot in your fantasy lineup. Keeper and dynasty league players should keep Isabella on the bench. Everyone else just keep him in mind should things change in the Cardinals' passing game.

player.seasonOutlook: Isabella is entering his second NFL season after Arizona selected him in the second round of the 2019 draft. The former UMass star was active for 15 games as a rookie, but managed to get just 14 targets on 149 snaps. He made the most of the limited action with a 9-189-1 receiving line, but inexplicably didn't get a shot to play a larger role. Isabella will be hard-pressed for a Year 2 breakout after DeAndre Hopkins was added to a WR rotation that also includes Larry Fitzgerald and Christian Kirk. There's hope for Isabella down the road, but the 23-year-old shouldn't be drafted in single-season leagues.

outlooksByWeek.1: The TE position was not a productive one for the Cardinals a year ago, but Arnold was the lone bright spot, acquired in December and immediately given a big opportunity in this offense. He hauled in a pair of touchdowns over the final three weeks, but still figures to be in a battle with Maxx Williams for looks in the passing game. Wait and see how this situation pans out before plugging any Arizona tight end into your lineup.
outlooksByWeek.2: Arnold matched Maxx Williams in terms of both snaps and targets in Week 1, but he was able to haul in his looks in the passing game while Williams was shut out. However, even if you combined the volume and production of the two Arizona tight ends, it wouldn't be good enough for fantasy. This position has proven to be one to avoid in the Kliff Kingsbury era.
outlooksByWeek.3: Arnold managed only two receptions on four targets as the Cardinals' primary tight end in Week 2 with Maxx Williams sidelined. Under head coach Kliff Kingsbury, the Cardinals have not provided their tight ends with a lot of opportunities in the passing game, so it's best to avoid Arnold for Week 3 against Detroit.

outlooksByWeek.1: Last season, the Cardinals had one of the worst fantasy D/ST units, and scored zero fantasy points over two matchups with the 49ers. Avoid them in Week 1 against their divisional rivals.
outlooksByWeek.2: Washington may have won in Week 1, but that victory wasn't based on a particularly strong offensive performance (239 total yards). It might be tempting to add the Cardinals to your fantasy lineup as a result of their prime matchup, but remember that this is a unit which has struggled to generate turnovers and sacks -- crucial elements in the fantasy point formula for D/STs. With three sacks and no takeaways in Week 1, it doesn't seem like the Cardinals are quite ready to be a starting D/ST in 2020.
outlooksByWeek.3: The Cardinals have looked great to start the season, including on defense, where they've allowed only 35 scoreboard points through two contests. They've yet to intercept a pass, but did force two turnovers against Washington and have seven total sacks this year. Detroit has been struggling out of the gate and, while this is all based on small samples, it might just be worth giving one of 2019's worst D/STs a shot in Week 3, given their recent history and a matchup at home against the Lions.

outlooksByWeek.1: Johnson hauled in 21 catches as a rookie, but that resulted in only 187 yards in the dink-and-dunk Arizona offense. He's still buried on the WR depth chart behind several talented players -- including newly acquired DeAndre Hopkins -- so he's best left on the waiver wire until things change in the Cardinals' passing game.

outlooksByWeek.3: Even with Maxx Williams out, Daniels does not figure to factor into Arizona's passing game all that often. Dan Arnold should be the team's top pass-catching tight end for the time being, but the Cardinals aren't great at involving that position in the offense, anyway. Keep Daniels on the waiver wire.

outlooksByWeek.1: Kirk didn't exactly "break out" in Year 2, but he picked up more work as a receiver and posted career-highs across the board. As Larry Fitzgerald gets even closer to riding off into retirement, Kirk should grow into a solid role as the No. 2 receiver behind DeAndre Hopkins. For now, though, with all three receivers in the lineup and a great pass-catching back in Kenyan Drake, it's hard to trust Kirk as anything more than a flex option, given so much competition for targets.
outlooksByWeek.2: Kirk couldn't find his rhythm in Week 1, catching only one of his five targets and failing to even pick up a yard on his lone reception. That said, five targets was still good enough for a three-way tie for second on the Arizona offense, which is about where we expected Kirk to be heading into the season. He's still a flex option, albiet a low-ceiling one, heading into Week 2 against a Washington defense that looks to be improved, though not unbeatable.
outlooksByWeek.3: Kirk saw fewer targets and played on fewer snaps than veteran Larry Fitzgerald in Week 2, which is a major issue for those relying on Kirk as a starting wideout in fantasy. If he's truly splitting work with Fitzgerald behind fantasy superstar DeAndre Hopkins, that likely leaves both as risky flex picks every week. Against the Lions' porous pass defense, consisder Kirk no more than a low-end WR3/flex option.

player.seasonOutlook: After flashing in a situational role as a rookie in 2018, Kirk saw a boost in usage and was the WR29 during 13 active weeks last season. The former second-round pick handled a very generous 24% target share in his first season with Kyler Murray in Kliff Kingsbury's system. However, he didn't see much work near the goal line (only four end-zone targets) and his 6.8 YPT ranked near the basement of the league. Moving forward, Kirk is a near lock for a big reduction in targets with superstar DeAndre Hopkins now sitting atop the depth chart. Kirk, who has already missed seven games due to injury, will also need to fend off Larry Fitzgerald, Hakeem Butler and Andy Isabella (among others) for targets. The 23-year-old is no more than a borderline flex in deeper leagues.

outlooksByWeek.1: Tight ends are not utilized that often in Kliff Kingsbury's offense, and Williams had poor production in 2019 as a result. Dan Arnold stepped in late in the season and made a bit of a splash, so it's possible he could reverse that trend, but Williams seems likely to be a non-factor in fantasy Week 1 against the 49ers.
outlooksByWeek.2: Williams and fellow tight end Dan Arnold both played on a healthy number of snaps and saw two targets each, but Williams failed to haul in either pass thrown his way. The TE position has not been productive for Arizona in quite some time, so there's no reason to consider either of these players for your Week 2 lineups.
